title: The R(S^1)-graded equivariant homotopy of THH(F_p)

title_detail.value: The R(S^1)-graded equivariant homotopy of THH(F_p)

summary:
The main result of this paper is the computation of TR^n_{\alpha}(F_p;p) for
\alpha in R(S^1). These R(S^1)-graded TR-groups are the equivariant homotopy
groups naturally associated to the S^1-spectrum THH(F_p), the topological
Hochschild S^1-spectrum. This computation, which extends a partial result of
Hesselholt and Madsen, provides the first example of the R(S^1)-graded
TR-groups of a ring. These groups arise in algebraic K-theory computations, and
are particularly important to the understanding of the algebraic K-theory of
non-regular schemes.

arXiv:0710.2938v2 [math.AT] 19 Sep 2008

The R(S1 )–graded equivariant homotopy of THH(Fp )
TEENA GERHARDT
The main result of this paper is the computation of TR nα (Fp ; p) for α ∈ R(S1 ).
These R(S1 )–graded TR–groups are the equivariant homotopy groups naturally associated to the S1 –spectrum THH(Fp ), the topological Hochschild S1 –spectrum.
This computation, which extends a partial result of Hesselholt and Madsen, provides the first example of the R(S1 )–graded TR–groups of a ring. These groups
arise in algebraic K –theory computations, and are particularly important to the
understanding of the algebraic K –theory of non-regular schemes.
19D55; 55P91

1 Introduction
Algebraic K –theory groups are generally very difficult to compute, but Bökstedt,
Hsiang, and Madsen [4] developed a homotopy-theoretic approach to algebraic K –
theory computations that has been quite fruitful. For every ring A, they defined a
cyclotomic trace map
trc : Kq (A) → TCq (A)
relating algebraic K –theory to topological cyclic homology. This map is highly nontrivial, and thus one can often understand algebraic K –theory by understanding topological cyclic homology (see, for instance, McCarthy [13]).
As an approach to computing topological cyclic homology, Hesselholt and Madsen
studied TR–theory [8, 9]. For a ring A and a fixed prime p,
TRnq (A; p) := πq (T(A)Cpn−1 ) = [Sq ∧ S1 /Cpn−1 + , T(A)]S1
where T(A) denotes the topological Hochschild S1 –spectrum of A and T(A)Cpn−1
denotes the Cpn−1 fixed point spectrum. These TR–groups come equipped with several
operators and relations which provide a rigid algebraic structure, making computations
possible. Topological cyclic homology is defined by a homotopy limit construction
that involves these operators. Thus understanding the TR–groups of a ring helps us to
understand its topological cyclic homology, and hence its algebraic K –theory.

 2

Teena Gerhardt

The topological Hochschild S1 –spectrum also has naturally associated equivariant homotopy groups which give a TR–theory graded by the complex representation ring of
the circle, R(S1 ). These groups arise naturally from the computational method outlined
above. Elements in the representation ring are given by formal differences of isomorphism classes of representations. For every α ∈ R(S1 ) we choose representatives β
and γ such that α = [β] − [γ]. Let Sβ denote the one–point compactification of the
representation β . Then the R(S1 )–graded TR–groups are defined as
TRnα (A; p) = [Sβ ∧ S1 /Cpn−1 + , Sγ ∧ T(A)]S1 .
These R(S1 )–graded groups first arose in computations of the algebraic K –theory of
non-regular schemes. For instance, for an Fp –algebra A, Hesselholt and Madsen [5]
expressed the K –theory of A[x]/(xe ) in terms of the R(S1 )–graded TR–groups of A.
While R(S1 )–graded TR–groups have been used in computations, there are no fully
computed examples for all α ∈ R(S1 ). The first computation to be done is that of
TRnα (Fp ; p), which is the main result of this paper.
Before stating the result of this computation, we introduce some notation. Let
ρp : S1 → S1 /Cp
be the isomorphism given by the pth root. Then we define a prime operation as follows:
for α ∈ R(S1 ),

for some virtual representation α ∈ R(S1 ).

computed explicitly. The argument is inductive, computing the group TRnα (Fp ; p) from

 4

Teena Gerhardt

We make a few observations about the results of these computations. If the integers |α|, |α′ |, . . . |α(n−1) | are all negative, then TRnα (Fp ; p) = 0. If the integers
|α|, |α′ |, . . . |α(n−1) | are all nonnegative, then TRnα (Fp ; p) ∼
= Z/pn . Thus the TR–
groups are easily understood for certain representations α. For any α, each of the
values li,n given in the computation of TRnα (Fp ; p) satisfies li,n ≤ n since TRn∗+α(Fp ; p)
is a TRn∗ (Fp ; p)–module, where ∗ denotes an even integer grading. However, the sum
l(n) = l1,n + l2,n + * * * + ln,n can be greater than n.
These computations extend a result of Hesselholt and Madsen [8, Proposition 9.1] for
representations of the form α = q − γ , q ∈ Z, γ a complex representation of S1 .
If the virtual representation α is of the form q + λ or q − λ for an actual complex
S1 –representation λ, then the groups TRnα (Fp ; p) are cyclic. The computations of the
TR–groups in these special cases is presented in Section 6.
In algebraic K –theory computations, it is the RO(S1 )–graded equivariant homotopy
groups, rather than the R(S1 )–graded groups, that arise most naturally. The even
dimensional real representations correspond to the complex representations, the computations for which appear in this paper. The groups graded by odd–dimensional real
representations must be computed slightly differently. These computations will appear
in joint work with Vigleik Angeltveit.

1.1 Organization
In Section 2 we discuss a homotopy-theoretic approach to algebraic K –theory computations. In particular, we recall the definition of TR–theory, and the operators and
relations on it. We then define the R(S1 )–graded TR–groups of a ring A. In Section
3 we study the fundamental long exact sequence of TR–theory, and its relation to the
norm–restriction sequence. Section 4 focuses on applying this relationship to execute
the first half of the induction step needed to prove Theorems 1.1 and 1.2. In Section
5 we finish the induction step by studying the map Γ̂. In Section 6 we put our earlier
results together to prove Theorems 1.1 and 1.2 and several corollaries.

1.2 Notation and conventions
Throughout this paper, A denotes a commutative ring, and p a fixed prime. The symbol
.
α denotes a virtual representation in R(S1 ). We use the convention a = b for a = μb,
where μ is a unit.

1.3 Acknowledgments
I would like to thank Lars Hesselholt for all of his support and guidance on this project.
I am also grateful to Vigleik Angeltveit for many helpful conversations.

2 Introduction to TR–groups
2.1 Overview of the approach
Let p be a fixed prime and A a commutative ring. In this section we outline a
homotopy-theoretic approach to algebraic K –theory computations. In particular, we
recall the definitions and properties of TR–groups, studied by Hesselholt and Madsen
(see [8, 9]).
To every ring A, there is an associated genuine S1 –spectrum, T(A), whose zero'th
space is naturally equivalent to the topological Hochschild space THH(A) defined by
Bökstedt [2]. This topological Hochschild spectrum is cyclotomic [8], which means in
particular that it comes equipped with an equivalence of S1 –spectra
r : ρ∗p (Ẽ ∧ T(A))Cp → T(A).
Here E denotes a free contractible S1 –space, and Ẽ is the cofiber of the map E+ → S0
given by projection onto the non-basepoint. This equivalence will be essential to the
construction of the long exact sequence of TR–groups in Section 3.
The S1 –spectrum structure of T(A) allows us to take Cpn –fixed point spectra of T(A)
for Cpn ⊂ S1 the cyclic group of order pn . Then inclusion of fixed points induces a
map
F : T(A)Cpn → T(A)Cpn−1
called the Frobenius. We also get a restriction map
R : T(A)Cpn → T(A)Cpn−1
which we define in Section 3. Using these operators, we can define the topological
cyclic homology spectrum of A. Let
TC(A; p) = [holimT(A)Cpn ]hF

It is possible to repeat the above, working with all natural numbers rather than just

For every ring A, we have a cyclotomic trace map [4] from the algebraic K –theory of
A to the topological cyclic homology spectrum of A
trc : K(A) → TC(A).
We can often understand algebraic K –theory by understanding topological cyclic
homology and this cyclotomic trace map. For example, for I ⊂ A a nilpotent ideal,
McCarthy's theorem [13] says that after profinite completion, there is an equivalence
∼

trc : K(A, I) −→ TC(A, I),
where K(A, I) and TC(A, I) denote relative K –theory and relative TC respectively.

2.2

Z–graded TR–groups

As an approach to understanding topological cyclic homology, Hesselholt and Madsen
studied TR–groups. For a ring A and a fixed prime p, let
TRn (A; p) = T(A)Cpn−1
and
TRnq (A; p) = πq (T(A)Cpn−1 ).
These TR–groups come equipped with several operators. Again, inclusion of fixed
points induces the Frobenius map
F : TRnq (A; p) → TRqn−1 (A; p).
This map has an associated transfer, the Verschiebung
V : TRqn−1 (A; p) → TRnq (A; p).
There is also a derivation d : TRnq (A; p) → TRnq+1 (A; p) induced from the circle action
on T(A). Lastly, we have a restriction map
R : TRnq (A; p) → TRqn−1 (A; p)
which we define in Section 3. These maps satisfy the relations FV = p, FdV = d, and
VF = V(1), where 1 is the multiplicative unit [1]n with Witt coordinates (1, 0, . . . 0) ∈

 The R(S1 )–graded equivariant homotopy of THH(Fp )

7

Wn (A) ∼
= TRn0 (A; p). For a more detailed introduction to TR–theory, see for instance
[8, 9].
We can define TC n (A; p) as the homotopy equalizer of the maps
R, F : TRn (A; p) → TRn−1 (A; p).
Then TC(A; p) is the homotopy limit of the spectra TC n (A; p). Thus understanding the
TR–groups of a ring helps us to understand its topological cyclic homology, and hence
its algebraic K –theory.
Computations are possible on the level of TR because the operators on TR–groups and
the relations between them give TR–groups a rigid algebraic structure. Indeed they
have the structure of a Witt complex over A [7].

2.3

R(S1 )–graded TR–groups

Recall that TR–groups are defined as
TRnq (A; p) = πq (T(A)Cpn−1 )
or equivalently
TRnq (A; p) ∼
= [Sq ∧ S1 /Cpn−1 + , T(A)]S1 .
To any S1 –spectrum T there are naturally associated equivariant homotopy groups
graded by the representation ring of the circle, R(S1 ). Elements in the representation
ring are given by formal differences of isomorphism classes of representations. For
every α ∈ R(S1 ) we choose representatives β and γ such that α = [β] − [γ]. Then
for an S1 –spectrum T , the group
πα (T) = [Sβ , Sγ ∧ T]S1 ,
the abelian group of maps in the S1 –stable category. Further, we get an R(S1 )–graded
Mackey functor π ∗ which for each subgroup C ⊂ S1 assigns
π α (T)(C) = [Sβ ∧ S1 /C+ , Sγ ∧ T]S1
Lewis and Mandell [12] have proven that this definition gives a well–behaved theory
of R(S1 )–graded homotopy groups. Although the theorem in the cited reference is
stated only for finite groups, the same method of proof works for compact lie groups.
We apply this R(S1 )–graded Mackey functor to the topological Hochschild S1 –spectrum
of A to get R(S1 )–graded TR–groups,
TRnα (A; p) = [Sβ ∧ S1 /Cpn−1 + , Sγ ∧ T(A)]S1 .

 8

Teena Gerhardt

These R(S1 )–graded TR–groups arise naturally in computations of algebraic K –theory.
Given a ring A and a pointed monoid Π, let A(Π) denote the pointed monoid algebra.
To study the algebraic K –theory of A(Π), we start with the topological Hochschild S1 –
spectrum of A(Π). Formal properties of the construction give a well known equivalence
of S1 –spectra [6]
∼
T(A) ∧ N cy (Π) → T(A(Π)).
where N cy (Π) denotes the cyclic bar construction on Π. For example, to understand
the topological Hochschild homology of A[x]/(xe ), A an Fp algebra, Hesselholt and
Madsen [5] studied
T(A) ∧ N cy (Πe ) ≃ T(A(Πe )) = T(A[x]/(xe )).
Here Πe denotes the pointed multiplicative monoid {0, 1, x, . . . xe−1 } where xe =
0. Using the above equivalence, and the definition of TR–groups, we obtain an
isomorphism
TRnq (A[x]/(xe ); p) ∼
= [Sq ∧ S1 /Cpn−1 + , T(A) ∧ N cy (Πe )]S1 .
Hesselholt and Madsen demonstrated how the S1 –equivariant homotopy type of N cy (Πe )
is built from representation spheres. Replacing N cy (Πe ) by these representation spheres
in the isomorphism above, we end up in the RO(S1 )–graded TR groups of A. Further,
for virtual representations α of the form arising in this example, the groups TRnα (Fp ; p)
are zero if the dimension of α as a real vector space is odd. The representations with
even real dimension correspond exactly to the complex representations of α. So this
expresses the algebraic K –theory of A[x]/(xe ) in terms of the R(S1 )–graded TR–groups
of the ring A.
The general principle here is that the R(S1 ) graded TR–groups of a ring A arise in
the computation of the ordinary TR–groups of the more complicated ring A(Π). By
considering different pointed monoids Π, one can use the R(S1 )–graded TR–groups of
A to understand the algebraic K –theory of a variety of rings A(Π). Using the pointed
monoid Π = {0, 1, x, x2 , . . . y, y2 , . . .} with xy = 0, Hesselholt [10] has similarly
computed the algebraic K –theory of the coordinate axes k[x, y]/(xy) in terms of the
RO(S1 )–graded TR–theory of k. Computations of representation–graded TR–theory
are fundamental to the computation of algebraic K –theory, particularly for non-regular
schemes.
In the non-equivariant case, computations of TR–groups are possible because the TR–
groups form a Witt complex, a rigid algebraic structure. We would like to define a
new algebraic structure, an R(S1 )–graded Witt complex, embodying the structure of
R(S1 )–graded TR. The first step in developing such an algebraic structure is completely

 The R(S1 )–graded equivariant homotopy of THH(Fp )

9

understanding an example of TR nα(A; p) for some ring A and all α ∈ R(S1 ). In this
paper we compute TR nα(Fp ; p) to provide such an example.
To study these R(S1 )–graded TR–groups, we first consider the operators and relations
that we have in this R(S1 )–graded version of TR (see [8]). Again, inclusion of fixed
points induces the Frobenius map,
F : TRnα (A; p) → TRαn−1 (A; p).
As in the integer graded case, this map has an associated transfer, the Verschiebung
V : TRαn−1 (A; p) → TRnα (A; p).
These maps again satisfy the relations FV = p, and VF = V(1). While these maps F
and V look similar to the Z–graded case, the restriction map is quite different. In the
R(S1 )–graded setting we have
R : TRnα (A; p) → TRαn−1
′ (A; p),
where α′ is as defined in the Introduction. We explain in Section 3 how this restriction
map is defined.
For a fixed representation α, TRn∗+α (A; p) is a module over TRn∗ (A; p), where ∗ is
an integer grading. In Section 5 we see that understanding this module structure is
essential to our main result.

3 Norm–Restriction Sequence
3.1 Construction of norm–restriction diagram

T(A) as a genuine S1 –spectrum, and all constructions take place in the S1 –stable
category. Our main tool in doing computations is the fundamental long exact sequence
of TR–groups and its relation to the norm–restriction cofiber sequence. Consider the
cofibration sequence
E+ → S0 → Ẽ
where E denotes a free contractible S1 –space and the first map is given by projection
onto the non-basepoint of S0 . We can smash this cofibration sequence with T −α to get
E+ ∧ T −α → T −α → Ẽ ∧ T −α .

The Tate spectrum

6.1 Special cases
We now interpret the main theorem in a few special cases.
Corollary 6.1 Let α be a virtual representation of the form α = q + β , q ∈ Z. Then
TRnα (Fp ; p) ∼
= Z/pL
where L is given as follows: Let m be such that |α(n−m) | > 0 ≥ |α(n−m+1) |. Let
rj = min(j, |α(n−j) | + 1). Set l1,m = rm . Letting j range from m + 1 to n,
l1,j = min(j, l1,j−1 + rj ).
Then L = l1,n .
Proof For a representation α of this form,
|α| ≥ |α′ | ≥ . . . ≥ |α(n−1) |
and given the hypotheses of the corollary,
r1 ≤ r2 ≤ . . . rm−1 ≤ 0 < rm ≤ . . . rn .
From the recursive definition in the proof of Theorem 1.2 we know that for j < m,
all li,j = 0, 1 ≤ i ≤ j. It follows that l1,m = rm , k1,m = 0, and li,m = ki,m = 0 for
2 ≤ i ≤ m. We show by induction that for all j from m to n, l1,j 6= 0, k1,j = 0,
and li,j = ki,j = 0 for 2 ≤ i ≤ j. We have already noted that this holds for j = m.
If it holds for j it holds for j + 1 by the recursive definition. Thus TRnα (Fp ; p) is a
cyclic group. The order of this group as stated in the corollary follows directly from
the recursive definition.

Corollary 6.2 Let α be a representation of the form α = q − γ , q ∈ Z. Then
TRnα (Fp ; p) ∼

where m is the number such that
|α(n−m) | ≥ 0 > |α(n−m−1) |.
Proof For a representation α of this form,
|α(n−1) | ≥ |α(n−2) | ≥ . . . ≥ |α|
and
rn ≤ rn−1 ≤ . . . ≤ rm+1 ≤ 0 < rm ≤ . . . ≤ r1 .
Following the recursive definition in the proof of Theorem 1.2, l1,1 = 1 and k1,1 = 0.
We show inductively that l1,j = j and k1,j = 0 for 1 ≤ j ≤ m. We have just observed
that this holds for j = 1. Now suppose it holds for j − 1. Then by the recursive
definition
l1,j = min(j, rj + gτ (w+1),j−1 ) = min(j, rj + l1,j−1 ) = j.
It is also clear that li,j = 0 for all 2 ≤ i ≤ j. So l1,m = m and li,m = 0 for 2 ≤ i ≤ m.
Continuing the recursion, we see that the group is unchanged for j > m, since in those
cases w = j − 1, and rj < 0 so the summand l1,j = 0. Thus TRnα (Fp ; p) ∼
= Z/pm .
The second corollary agrees with the result given by Hesselholt and Madsen in this case
[8, Proposition 9.1]. We have now seen that if α is an actual complex representation
of S1 , or zero minus an actual representation, the TR–groups we are calculating are all
cyclic.
